case_name: State of Bihar v. Rai Bahadur Hurdut Roy Motilal Jute Mills

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.678 of 1957 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1956 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 188 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.678 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1956-of the Patna High Court, in Misc. Judicial Case No. 188 of 1955.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 546 of 1958 and 115 of 1959 are appeals from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1957 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 116 and 215 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: WITH Civil Appeals Nos. 546 of 1958 and 115 of 1959. Appeals from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1957, of the Patna High Court, in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 116 and 215 of 1956.

facts.text: The appeals were filed by the State of Bihar against three registered dealers with certificate under Art. 132(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is a group of three appeals which have been filed in this Court by the State of Bihar  hereinafter called the appellant  against three separate registered dealers with a certificate issued by the Patna High Court Under Art. 132 1  of of the Constitution

facts.text: Rai Bahadur Hurdut Roy Motilal Jute Mills, Katihar was a registered dealer under the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947 carrying on business of manufacture and sale of gunny bags, Hessian and other jute products at Katihar in Purnea district.

anchor.surface_text: Rai Bahadur Hurdut Roy Motilal Jute Mills, Katihar  hereinafter called the first respondent  was at the, material time registered as a dealer under the Act and was carrying oil business of manufacture and sale of gunny bags, Hessian and other jute products at Katihar in the district of Purnea.

facts.text: During April 1, 1950 to March 31, 1951, the first respondent sold and despatched wares worth Rs. 92,24,386 to dealers outside Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: During the period April 1, 1950, to March 31, 195 1, the said respondent sold and despatched its ware worth about Rs. 92,24,386 to dealers outside the State of Bihar

facts.text: The first respondent realised Rs. 2,11,222-9-6 as sales tax from dealers outside Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: and realised a sum of Rs. 2,11,222-9-6 as sales tax from such dealers.

facts.text: Assessment of the first respondent for the period was taken up by Superintendent of Sales Tax, Purnea on May 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The said respondents assessment to sales tax for the relevant period was taken up by the Superintendent of Sales Tax, Purnea  hereinafter called the second respondent  on May 31, 1953

facts.text: In assessment, turnover of Rs. 92,24,386 was exempted from tax following Supreme Court decision in State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: When the first respondents assessment was taken up by the second respondent his attention was invited to this Courts decision in the case of the United Motors  1  he followed the said decision and held that  1  1953 S.C.R. 1069. the turn over of Rs. 92,24,386-1-6 on account of despatch of manufactured jute products to out-of-Stat buyers was exempted from the levy of tax

facts.text: Notice under s.14A issued to first respondent on June 18, 1954 to show cause why Rs. 2,11,222-9-6 should not be forfeited.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the second respondent proceeded against the first respondent under s. 14A of the Act and issued a numberice in that behalf on June 18, 1954. By this numberice the first respondent was called upon to show cause why the entire amount of Rs. 2,11,222-9-6 which had been recovered by him as sales tax from the dealers should number be forfeited to Government.

facts.text: Order of forfeiture passed against first respondent on February 10, 1955 directing deposit of Rs. 2,11,222-9-6.

anchor.surface_text: This order was passed on February 10, 1955. It shows that the second respondent thought that the matter raised for his decision was simple the first respondent had companylected the amount in question as tax under the Act from his customers

facts.text: First respondent filed petition in Patna High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 challenging the forfeiture order.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent then applied to the Patna High Court, tinder Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the said order.

facts.text: Patna High Court allowed the petition, set aside forfeiture order on August 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number companysider the first companytention raised before it it dealt with the two companystitutional points urged by the first respondent and found in his favour on both of them. On these findings the petition filed by the first respondent was allowed, the impugned order of forfeiture was set aside

facts.text: Patna High Court issued certificate under Art. 132(1) to State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the said High Court under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Section 33 of the Act was enacted on April 4, 1951 with retrospective effect from January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This section was enacted on April 4,1951, but it has been expressly made retrospective as from January 26, 1950. Therefore at the material time this section must be deemed to have been in operation.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment in State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd. before the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile Art. 286 of the Constitution along with other articles was companysidered by this Court in the State of Bombay Anr. v. The United Motors  India  Ltd. Ors.  1 .

facts.text: The three appeals raise common question under proviso to s.14A of Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947 regarding validity of forfeiture orders.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in each one of the three appeals are similar, though number exactly the same, but they raise a companymon question of law under the proviso to s. 14A of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947  Act XIX of 1947   hereinafter called the-Act . Orders of forfeiture have been passed against the three registered dealers

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 678 of 1957 argued as principal appeal, decision to govern others.

anchor.surface_text: By companysent Civil Appeal No. 678 of 1957, has been argued before us as the principal appeal and it has been companyceded that our decision in that appeal will govern the two other appeals.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Gajendragadkar J. on November 26, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. November 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-

facts.text: Superintendent held that first respondent contravened s.14A and r.19 by collecting tax on exempt turnover.

anchor.surface_text: He also held that the first respondent had represented to the, purchasers that the amount was chargeable as sales tax under the Act and as such the first respondent had clearly companytravened the explicit provisions of s. 14A of the Act read with r. 19 of the Bihar Sales Tax Rules

facts.text: Supreme Court held that proviso to s.14A not attracted, forfeiture order unjustified and illegal.

anchor.surface_text: An allowable deduction under the said proviso was number the same thing as exclusion of a part of the turn-over on the basis of s. 33 1  a  1  of the Act. It stands on an entirely different footing. Transactions which fall within the said section are in substance outside the Act and numbertax can be imposed on them. The transaction in question did number, therefore, fall within the proviso to r.19 and the proviso to S. 14A was number attracted and the order of forfeiture passed against the respondent was unjustified and illegal.

facts.text: Transactions under s.33(1)(a)(i) are outside the Act, no tax can be imposed.

anchor.surface_text: transactions which attract the provisions of the said section are in substance outside the scope of the Act and numbertax can be imposed on them at all.

facts.text: Registered dealers collected and paid tax on inter-state transactions before United Motors decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that during the material period and in the years preceding it registered dealers used to pay tax in respect of transactions which were really number liable to be taxed under s. 33 1  a  i  and such tax was being received by the appellant.

facts.text: Notification levied tax at three pies on goods despatched outside Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed it is companymon ground that the numberification issued for the material period levied a tax at three pies on the goods in question if the sales tax authority is satisfied that the goods have been despatched by or on behalf of the dealer to any person outside the Province of Bihar.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts. The decision of this appeal governs Civil Appeals Nos. 546 of 1958 and 115 of 1959.

holdings.text: The proviso to s.14A was not attracted and the order of forfeiture passed against the respondent was unjustified and illegal

anchor.surface_text: An allowable deduction under the said proviso was number the same thing as exclusion of a part of the turn-over on the basis of s. 33 1  a  1  of the Act. It stands on an entirely different footing. Transactions which fall within the said section are in substance outside the Act and numbertax can be imposed on them. The transaction in question did number, therefore, fall within the proviso to r.19 and the proviso to S. 14A was number attracted and the order of forfeiture passed against the respondent was unjustified and illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes allowable deductions under ss.5,6,7,8 from exclusions under s.33 which place transactions outside Act's scope entirely; proviso to r.19 applies only to former

holdings.text: Transactions which fall within s.33(1)(a)(i) are in substance outside the Act and no tax can be imposed on them

anchor.surface_text: transactions which attract the provisions of the said section are in substance outside the scope of the Act and numbertax can be imposed on them at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33 retrospectively excludes inter-state transactions from Act's ambit per United Motors interpretation of Art.286; not mere deduction but non-applicability

holdings.text: Claim for exclusion under s.33(1)(a)(i) is not an allowable deduction from gross turnover within proviso to r.19

anchor.surface_text: Construing the proviso on this assumption, can it be said that in respect of the part of the first respondents turnover which is in question a deduction was allowable within the meaning of the proviso?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to r.19 references deductions per explanation to s.5 (ss.6,7,8 tax-free/exempt); s.33 is substantive exclusion outside Act, not deduction postulated within it

holdings.text: No provision of s.14A was contravened by the collection

anchor.surface_text: Then as to the argument about the contravention of s. 14A itself it is difficult to appreciate how any provision of s. 14A can be said to have been contravened.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14A authorizes collection per prescribed restrictions (r.19); collection on non-Act transactions falls outside but does not contravene its negative prohibitions

holdings.text: Proviso to s.14A cannot be invoked against the respondent; order of forfeiture unjustified and illegal

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the proviso to s. 14A cannot be invoked against the first respondent and so the order of forfeiture passed against him by the second respondent is unjustified and illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No contravention of r.19 proviso hence no basis for forfeiture under s.14A proviso; prefers reasonable construction avoiding penalty where transactions outside Act

anchor.surface_text: An allowable deduction under the said proviso was number the same thing as exclusion of a part of the turn-over on the basis of s. 33 1  a  1  of the Act. It stands on an entirely different footing. Transactions which fall within the said section are in substance outside the Act and numbertax can be imposed on them. The transaction in question did number, therefore, fall within the proviso to r.19 and the proviso to S. 14A was number attracted and the order of forfeiture passed against the respondent was unjustified and illegal.
The result is the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. The decision of this appeal governs Civil Appeals Nos. 546 of 1958 and 115 of 1959.
